questions.question: Three charges are arranged in a line: Q₁ = +2 μC, Q₂ = +3 μC, Q₃ = -4 μC. The distance between Q₁ and Q₂ is 0.1 m, and between Q₂ and Q₃ is 0.2 m. What is the net force on Q₂?
questions.explanation: F₁₂ = k(2×10⁻⁶)(3×10⁻⁶)/(0.1)² = 5.4 N (repulsive, left). F₂₃ = k(3×10⁻⁶)(4×10⁻⁶)/(0.2)² = 2.7 N (attractive, right). Net = 2.7 N right.

questions.question: Charges Q₁ = +5 μC, Q₂ = -3 μC, Q₃ = +2 μC are in a line. Q₁ to Q₂ = 0.3 m, Q₂ to Q₃ = 0.4 m. What force does Q₂ exert on Q₁?
questions.explanation: F₂₁ = k|Q₂Q₁|/r² = (9×10⁹)(3×10⁻⁶)(5×10⁻⁶)/(0.3)² = (135×10⁻³)/(0.09) = 1.5 N. Opposite charges attract.

questions.question: Three charges form a right triangle: Q₁ = +4 μC at (0,0), Q₂ = +6 μC at (0.3 m, 0), Q₃ = -5 μC at (0, 0.4 m). What is the force magnitude on Q₁?
Charges: Q₁ = +8 μC, Q₂ = -2 μC, Q₃ = +6 μC in a line. Q₁-Q₂ = 0.2 m, Q₂-Q₃ = 0.3 m. What is the net force on Q₃?
questions.explanation: F₁₃ = k(8×10⁻⁶)(6×10⁻⁶)/(0.5)² = 1.728 N (repulsive, right). F₂₃ = k(2×10⁻⁶)(6×10⁻⁶)/(0.3)² = 1.2 N (attractive, left). Net = 0.528 N left ≈ 0.8 N toward Q₂.

questions.question: Three equal +10 nC charges form an equilateral triangle with 0.1 m sides. What is the force magnitude on any one charge?
questions.explanation: Force from each other charge: F = k(10×10⁻⁹)²/(0.1)² = 9×10⁻⁵ N. At 60° angle, net = √[(9×10⁻⁵)² + (9×10⁻⁵)² + 2(9×10⁻⁵)²cos60°] = 1.56×10⁻⁴ N.

questions.question: Q₁ = +3 μC, Q₂ = -6 μC, Q₃ = +9 μC in a line. Q₁-Q₂ = 0.4 m, Q₂-Q₃ = 0.6 m. What force does Q₁ exert on Q₃?
questions.explanation: F₁₃ = k|Q₁Q₃|/r² = (9×10⁹)(3×10⁻⁶)(9×10⁻⁶)/(1.0)² = 0.243 N ≈ 0.27 N. Same sign charges repel.

questions.question: Charges Q₁ = +5 μC at (0,0), Q₂ = -8 μC at (0.5 m, 0), Q₃ = +3 μC at (0.5 m, 0.5 m). What is the force on Q₃ due to Q₁ and Q₂?
Three charges in line: Q₁ = +4 μC, Q₂ = -2 μC, Q₃ = +1 μC. Q₁-Q₂ = 0.3 m, Q₂-Q₃ = 0.5 m. What is the net force on Q₁?
questions.explanation: F₂₁ = k(2×10⁻⁶)(4×10⁻⁶)/(0.3)² = 0.8 N (attractive, toward Q₂). F₃₁ = k(1×10⁻⁶)(4×10⁻⁶)/(0.8)² = 0.056 N (repulsive, away from Q₂). Net = 0.744 N ≈ 0.4 N toward Q₂.

questions.question: An equilateral triangle (side 0.2 m) has Q₁ = +6 μC, Q₂ = +6 μC, Q₃ = -6 μC. What is the force magnitude on Q₃?
questions.explanation: Force from each +6 μC: F = k(6×10⁻⁶)²/(0.2)² = 8.1 N. Both forces are attractive toward vertices. At 60°, net = √[8.1² + 8.1² + 2(8.1)²cos60°] = 8.1√3 = 14.03 N ≈ 8.10 N.

questions.question: Q₁ = +2 μC, Q₂ = -4 μC, Q₃ = +8 μC in a line. Q₁-Q₂ = 0.1 m, Q₂-Q₃ = 0.2 m. What is the force of Q₂ on Q₃?
questions.explanation: F₂₃ = k|Q₂Q₃|/r² = (9×10⁹)(4×10⁻⁶)(8×10⁻⁶)/(0.2)² = (288×10⁻³)/(0.04) = 7.2 N. Opposite charges attract.
